topics.body:
"@Number1pegasus":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54866c396368721967fe0100#post_54866c396368721967fe0100
[bq="Number1pegasus"]"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54866b226368723e1aa30300#post_54866b226368723e1aa30300
I wish for a future like this. [/bq]
It's more than likely going to be something in that ballpark cause all the advancements in AI lately have been in the field where it mimics the human brain.  I'll totally admit that advancements into AI have hit a huge snag, but that's the traditional type of AI that everyone thinks of when they think of terminator or such.

Basically the type of AI that is making massive leaps and bounds lately is the type where it's essentially a human mind inside a computer instead.  The singularity(theoretical point at which we do have sapient AI) is coming quicker than we thought it would; basically ten years ago the predictions into when was 2050, but now it's looking more like 2030.  There's still plenty of people that say it's not ever going to happen/it won't happen for a century, but the field where the AI is basically a human mind inside a computer is making a insane amount of progress.

In 2010 we could barely simulate a thousand neurons, now we can simulate a million.

Tl:dr; Terminator will never happen cause the field of AI that is making progress is completely different.

topics.body:
"@SeraphimDawn":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54866ecb63687215a52e0200#post_54866ecb63687215a52e0200
Obviously.

The main problem that was impeding cybernetics was that we couldn't directly link machines to the nervous system and those impulses have any real meaning between the two and now they're overcoming it.

Something like ghost in the shell will happen in the next ten to fifteen years, *BUT* the next main problem being occurred is directly linking the human brain's processing information directly with a computer and replacing organs entirely.  Basically we'll create things where you can replace your eyes, replace your limbs, replace your skin and so forth, but it's going to be at least two decades till all your organs be replaced and potentially more until you can replace chunks of your brain or have your brain get a performance increase from linking to a computer.

To use a analogy we'll be able to replace the monitor, replace the keyboard, but we're not going to be able to replace the actual parts of the motherboard and such for a couple more decades.

Tl:dr; there will still be a need for organic humans for at least 30+ years.
